slides.title: Why Go?
slides.content:
# Simplicity & Speed ðŸš€

- **Compiled:** Compiles exceptionally fast to native binary.
- **GC:** Garbage Collected.
- **Concurrency:** Built from ground up for multicore utilization.
- **Simple:** Smallest syntax footprint of modern languages.

slides.title: Goroutines
slides.content:
# Lightweight Threads ðŸ§µ

A Goroutine is a function executing concurrently.

They are incredibly cheap (2KB each). You can spin up thousands easily.

```go
go myFunction() // Runs in background
```

slides.title: Channels
slides.content:
# Pipelines ðŸ“¨

Channels invoke the philosophy: "Do not communicate by sharing memory; share memory by communicating."

They let goroutines pass data safely.

```go
ch := make(chan int)
go func() { ch <- 42 }() // Send
val := <-ch // Receive
```

slides.title: Interfaces
slides.content:
# Implicit Interfaces ðŸŽ­

No `implements` keyword.

If a Type implements the methods of an Interface, it satisfies the interface automatically.

Duck Typing: "If it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck."

slides.title: Keyword Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which keyword is used to start a new lightweight thread (Goroutine)?

slides.title: Error Handling
slides.content:
# No Exceptions ðŸš«

Go does not have try/catch.

Errors are values returned from functions.

```go
f, err := os.Open("file.txt")
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
```
It forces you to handle errors explicitly immediately.

slides.title: Structs & Methods
Go Modules
slides.content:
# Dependency Management ðŸ“¦

Standard since Go 1.11.

`go.mod` file tracks dependencies.

`go get github.com/gin-gonic/gin` adds it to your project.

slides.title: Standard Library
slides.content:
# Robust Std Lib ðŸ“š

Go has a production-ready HTTP server built-in.

```go
http.HandleFunc("/", handler)
http.ListenAndServe(":8080", nil)
```
You often don't need a framework, but **Gin** and **Echo** are popular helpers.

slides.title: Defer
slides.content:
# Cleanup ðŸ§¹

`defer` schedules a function call to run just before the surrounding function returns.

```go
f, _ := os.Open("file")
defer f.Close() // Guaranteed to run
// Process file...
```

Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Go ðŸŽ“

System Programming.

- **Goroutines:** Cheap concurrency.
- **Channels:** Safe communication.
- **Error Handling:** Explicit `if err != nil`.
- **Structs:** No classes.
- **Defer:** Cleanup made easy.
